etymology.description: Pictogram – grass blades; duplication of 屮 (“grass”).
etymology.interpretation: Shows multiple blades sprouting by doubling 屮, evoking a patch of grass or vegetation. The graphic later served as the grass radical atop many characters and relates to the original top of 春 in its early form (萅).
etymology.simplification: As a component it was standardized to the two-stroke 艹 for stroke economy and print clarity; as an independent word in modern Chinese, it is replaced by 草.

examples.chinese: 古文中常写作“艸”，今作“草”(古文中常寫作「艸」，今作「草」。)
examples.pinyin: Gǔwén zhōng cháng xiězuò “cǎo”, jīn zuò “cǎo”.
examples.english: In classical texts it was often written as “艸”, while today it is written “草”.

examples.chinese: 春天里，草木茂盛(春天裡，艸木茂盛)。
